definition: a sailing ship used in the past for fighting
a long narrow piece of cloth worn around the neck, especially by men, with a knot in front
money that you give to somebody who has provided a service for you
money that is given to employees when they leave their job
a female tiger
without any conditions or limits
the state of accepting what happens without reacting or trying to fight against it
when a horse neighs it makes a long high sound
a lie. People often say ‘untruth’ to avoid saying ‘lie’.
the state of being false
a feeling of worry or excitement that you have when you feel that something is going to happen, somebody is going to tell you some news, etc.
a plant that grows in the sea, or on rocks at the edge of the sea. There are many different types of seaweed, some of which are eaten as food.
dried naturally by the heat of the sun
to dry something using the air; to become dry in the air
a bright or metallic blue colour
a million pixels (= very small individual areas on a computer screen), used to measure the quality of a digital screen or image
an electronic device, like a cigarette in shape, that contains nicotine that you can take into your lungs through your mouth, and that produces vapour that looks like cigarette smoke
one of the two bones that form the sides of the pelvis
fizzy water (= water with bubbles) used as a drink on its own or to mix with alcoholic drinks or fruit juice (originally made with sodium bicarbonate)
a glass of soda
a sweet fizzy drink (= a drink with bubbles) made with soda water, a fruit taste and sometimes ice cream
a chemical substance in common use that is a compound of sodium
